Description: Convex glass roundel; possibly a gaming piece or architectural inlay; circular; solid with flat base, with small cavity in the centre of the base, probably the imprint of a nail which held the object in place while it was modelled and the thread decoration applied to the top; the top is decorated with a cruciform pattern composed of black threads with faded threads in a second colour; four "eyes" in the same colours are placed in the four spaces created by the cross.
Curator's comments: Similar objects excavated in 16th-13th century contexts at the same site, plus Nuzi (Mesopotamia), Choga Zanbil (Iran) and possibly Thebes (Egypt).
Bibliographic references: Barag 1985a / Catalogue of Western Asiatic glass in the British Museum, Volume I (12; p. 44, fig. 1, pl. 1)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: Room 57: Ancient Syria [Syrian Room], Easter 1982-.
Condition: Cracks; small portion missing; surface faded and now grey in colour; original turquoise-blue colour well-preserved in core of the object
